title: A new American tradition — the double quinceañera
text:
Introducing the Double Quinceañera.

Social media is full of this new thing — princessey parties complete with tiaras and plenty of pink — celebrating Latina women turning 30.

AD

Why?

There are the women who throw a Double Quince for the fun of throwing a party. And it’s easy to snark at them as indulgent divas. A bridezilla without a groom.

AD

Or you can see this as a feminist update of the moldy debutante tradition, when a girl entering womanhood is officially placed on the market. Here I am, world. This is who I’ve become, at 30. And I don’t need a wedding to wear tulle.

“And, really, how often do we take time to celebrate a woman’s aging?” said Iulia Gheorghiu, Gortaire’s friend and chief of operations for this caper.

Or maybe there are the women who want a do-over of how their parents commemorated it.

“Whatever your story, turning 30 offers the chance to do it all your way,” said a story about the “doble quince” trend in the Latina-focused digital publication Mitú. “The doble quince has become a popular way for Latinas to celebrate their heritage and their 30s in style.”

AD

But you can also consider the women like Gortaire, who never had the traditional fete popular in Latino and Caribbean cultures celebrating a girl’s entry into womanhood.

AD

It had been only five years since Gortaire’s family arrived from Ecuador and settled in Florida when she turned 15, and they were saving and struggling as new immigrants. So her 15th birthday was a simple family affair, her gift a silver cross. No florid swirls of taffeta, music and banquet spreads that many quinceañeras now feature.

Karen Castro knows the feeling — she had it doubly bad. Her parents were also Ecuadoran immigrants. And growing up in Ohio, she saw more-established immigrant families throwing extravagant quinceañeras. She also watched the country club crowd throw Sweet 16 parties for their daughters. She turned 15, then 16, with little fanfare.

AD

“I’m thinking that maybe I’ll do this, too,” said Karen, who is 29 and will turn 30 in February. She was a friend of Gortaire’s in graduate school and now works for the U.S. State Department, having just returned from a long assignment in China. She’s ready “to have that party and sort of celebrate my life today. Why not?”

AD

This makes the Double Quinceañera a third-culture tradition, the bridge that children of immigrants build between old-world culture and their lives as Americans today.

In Ecuador, they call a quinceañera a “fiesta rosada,” or “pink party,” because they are usually drenched in pink. But Gortaire cringed at the thought of a full-on Pepto-Bismol scenario.

AD

“I have a pink tulle skirt that I got online,” she explained, in the final weeks of her 20s, when we met to talk about her party. “But I’m going to wear it with these silvery boots and a jean jacket with pearl accents. I can’t take it too far; that’s not me. It has to be genuine.”

On Saturday, she made her grand entrance at a trendy beer garden, Hook Hall in the Parkview neighborhood of Northwest Washington. It had picnic tables and cornhole boards on AstroTurf, and the whole scene was aglow with crisscrossed strings of bistro lights.

AD

They created a custom drink for this fiesta. “You get to drink at a double quinceañera!” Gheorghiu reminded me, as she ticked off the reasons a woman turning 30 should take the time to celebrate her life. (The drink is called the “Franny” — elderflower, grapefruit juice, club soda and gin — and it’s pink.)

AD

Some traditional quinceañeras have attendants in matching pastel dresses, bridesmaid-style, and guests in gowns and even tuxedos.

Gortaire’s guests came in sequins, suits, jeans, gowns and leather, the best outfits they could summon to celebrate their slightly eccentric friend.

As her cousin’s Latin-pop playlist boomed, Gortaire’s diverse life unfurled around her. There was her improv group crowd, the female drum squad she performs with, colleagues from her event planning company, graduate school roomies and (human) friends from the dog park.

AD

The evening officially began as everyone raised the glasses of pink Frannys and a friend in sequined pants crowned Gortaire with a tiara.

AD

She joked that she may have to go to bed early after the party. “I’m 30 now, so I have to get up to go to the farmers market.”

After plenty of drinks and the cutting of a cake, she performed the traditional candle ceremony, handing a lit candle to the people who have been important in her life.

“It’s about celebrating who I’ve become at 30, and the people who helped me get there,” she said.

She had little speeches thanking the indispensable work colleague, the roommates, the neighbors who took care of her, the ride-or-die friends.

Then she had a surprise for most of the people there — something that would make her unique event even more significant.

AD

“This next one is for me,” she said, holding the final candle. “Specifically a part of myself that I always knew was in me, but I didn’t quite recognize what it was,” she said.

AD

Deep breath.

“So, to the queer little Francis within and amongst all of you, I want to recognize her and be proud of her and from this day forward, be proud and open about that part of my life and identity,” she said.

Her friends gasped and cheered, some got a little teary. Many of them had no idea Gortaire is queer.

It was a coming out, after all, of a fully realized woman. In a tiara.

description: Celebrating 30, with tulle, tiaras and a surprise announcement.
